content: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.

content: Ah yes, the good old days. Before we had unemployment compensation, workers compensation, social security, safe work enviroments mandated by OSHA or minimum wages. Back when you could stand in line for hours to get a watery bowl of soup and a piece of stale bread. Someone is viewing the past through rose colored glasses. In the case of employers who pay the minimum wage, they will simply hire fewer people. Same as when the minimum wage is raised excessivly. There's another flaw in this bill. The employees are not eligible till after working a year. Most probation periods are only 90 days. But after a year it'll be "Sorry Bob, but I'm gonna have to let you go. It's been a year. Can't afford to keep you. Junior will take over your job tomorrow." Well, there maqy have been more manufacturing jobs in the USA that paid "living wages." Then unions like the UAW declared their people can't tighten lug nuts on the assembly line for less than 70 bucks an hour. Not suprisingly there are non-union workers in Mexico that will.

content: quote: Originally posted by stec74: Let's look at the economic impact of this proposed bill: If a company has 100 employees that would be 100 weeks of lost labor or having to hire 2 new employees to make up for the loss. At $6.55 per hour for 40 hours a week that equals $262 per week per employee or $524 a week total in extra costs to the employer. 56 weeks in a year times $524 equals an extra cost of $29,344 per year to the employer. That is a substantial cost to a small business that will not be absorbed by the business but made up for in other ways like price increases or layoffs.
